title: 111_s264
content: The Act titled "E-Centives Act of 2009" increases matching payments under Medicaid for health information technology. Section 1903 of the Social Security Act is amended to provide enhanced payments to states that offer incentives for healthcare providers using certified health information technology. Enhanced payments to states for incentive payments made for meaningful use of health information technology before January 1, 2010. States must submit an application detailing incentive payments allocation and implementation timeline. States must submit an application outlining payment incentives implementation timeline, information dissemination plan, health information technology assessment, and any additional information required by the Secretary. The payment to a State under this subsection for providing incentive payments is based on the enhanced FMAP percentage, with adjustments for different quarters between 2010 and 2014. The total amount of payments under this subsection is limited to $500,000,000 per fiscal year, with reductions made if the limit is exceeded. Duplicative payments are prohibited. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant organizations, determines certification requirements for health information technology under this subsection. The Secretary will use interim certification requirements for health information technology until determined. Standard measures for meaningful use of certified health information technology will be published for providers to demonstrate meaningful use. The Secretary may establish alternative measures for the meaningful use of certified health information technology, including self-certification, submission of clinical data, and other specified means. Different measures may be applied based on the stage of implementation or adoption of the technology. Different measures may be applied based on the stage of implementation or adoption of the technology. Additionally, payments for electronic information and eligibility systems, patient registries, coordination of benefits and services, and provider training are provided to states under the program. The State shall submit an application to qualify for payments under the program, including electronic information systems and patient registries. Payments to States shall be 90 percent of the sums expended for such systems after January 1, 2010. The State can receive payments for electronic information systems and patient registries starting on January 1, 2010. The payments cover design, development, installation, and staff training. 75 percent of the expenses incurred by the State after January 1, 2010, are eligible for reimbursement. The term 'electronic information and eligibility system' means a system for determining eligibility and exchanging information. Payments cover design, development, installation, and staff training. 75 percent of expenses incurred by the State after January 1, 2010, are eligible for reimbursement. MEDICAID TRANSFORMATION PAYMENTS REPORT. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress by June 30, 2009, on Medicaid transformation payments. The report should include a description of the financial costs and benefits, entities involved, reduction in unnecessary care, and an analysis of information from reports submitted by States. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit a report to Congress by June 30, 2009, on Medicaid transformation payments. The report should cover the impact of funded methods on healthcare quality, privacy, and security of health information, as well as the interconnectedness between providers, State Medicaid programs, and other programs for low-income populations. Additionally, the report should assess the administrative burden reduction on these programs. Additionally, it should assess the contribution of the payments to public health and reporting goals.
